div.l: Thise · iiij · sparcles / longen̄ vn to eld
Oure old lymmes mow wele be vnweld
But will ne shall faile / that is soth
And yitte haue I alwey / a coltyssh tooth
As many a yere / as it is passed henne
Seth þat my tappe of lyf bygan̄ to renne
For sekerly whan I was born̄ anon̄
Deth drough the tap̄pe of lyf / and lete it gon̄
And eủere seth hath so the tapp̄pe yronne
Till þat all most all empty is þe tonne
The streme of lyf / now droppeth on̄ þe chymbe
The sely tung / may wel rynge and chymbe
Of wrecchednesse þat passed / is full yore
Wᵗith old folk / save dotage is no more
Whan that our host hadde herde þis ʆsermonyng
He gan̄ to speke as lordly as a kyng
And seid what amounteth all this wit
Why shall we all day speke of holy writ
The deuyll made a Reve / for to preche
Or a souter a shipman or a leche
Sey forth thy tale / and tarie nat the tyme
Lo Depford and it is half wey pryme
Lo Grenwych there many a shrewe is in
It were hye tyme thy tale to begyn
Now sirs koth this Oswold the reve
I pray yoᵘ all / that ye nat yoᵘ greve
Though I answere / and somdele sette his howe
For liefull is / wᵗith force / force of showe
This dronken̄ Miller͗e / hath told vs here
How that begiled was a Carpentere
ꝐParauenture in skorne for I am one
And by yoʳur leue I shal hīm quyte anone
Right in his cherles t̉ermes woll I speke
I pray to god / his nek mot to breke
He can̄ wele in myn̄ yie se a stalk
But in his owen̄ he can̄ nat se a balk
